ground_truth: Joe and Charles enter, and Charles grabs a roll. Joe nods as Jack forces a smile and closes the bathroom door, leaving Joe stunned and heartsick. Joe and his father, in civvies, sit beside each other at the counter. Jack pulls out a pamphlet and places it on the table, showing Joe a pamphlet for Hewitt Sports Camp, with images of happy, smiling, healthy athletic kids. Joe looks back at the pamphlet, his other hand coming up from under the table, and Jack sees that Joe is holding his mother's locket. Jack wants to cry again and throw the locket away but just turns away as Joe stares at the pamphlet. In Joe's room, he holds a paintbrush, working on a Quasimodo model at his desk. The room, recently devoid of a mother's oversight, is messy, with comic books and other plastic models built and painted by Joe, including cars, creatures, and a train. All the boys look on, and their faces brighten. Headlights appear, and the boys stand as a yellow Buick stops beside them, driven by 14-year-old Alice Dainard. She sees Joe, looking away, annoyed, as all the boys silently wait. She considers, shakes her head, and the boys excitedly scramble into the car. The Buick crosses the nighttime horizon through a rural landscape. Cary messes with the radio, Alice looks at him in the rearview, their eyes hold a beat, she takes the Twizzler he offers, and looks back to the road. Joe walks past Alice, who watches him, while Martin sits alone, reading and memorizing lines, and she looks at him as if searching for something. Joe stops stippling, the tension is almost too much, and he indicates the sponge for make-up, which she uses. Joe starts applying make-up to Alice's eyelids, feeling something provocative in being so close to her with her eyes closed. Alice is made up, wearing a coat with a purse, as Martin, in a tie, faces her, both looking over script pages while Charles adjusts the camera. Joe observes, holding the boom mike as Preston wears an overcoat. Suddenly, a pop! Everyone jumps as Cary, laughing, explodes a firecracker. Martin and Alice perform as Detective John Hathaway and Mrs. Rebecca Hathaway, with Preston acting in the background. Finally, we focus tightly on Joe, watching Alice.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Joe and Charles arrive, and Charles seizes a bun. Joe acknowledges as Jack compels a grin and shuts the lavatory door, leaving Joe shocked and heartsick. Joe and his father, in casuals, sit beside each other at the bar. Jack extracts a brochure and places it on the table, showing Joe a brochure for Hewitt Athletics Camp, with pictures of joyful, grinning, healthy sporty children. Joe glances back at the brochure, his other hand rising from beneath the table, and Jack perceives that Joe is clutching his mother's locket. Jack desires to weep again and discard the locket but just turns away as Joe gazes at the brochure. In Joe's room, he grasps a paintbrush, working on a Quasimodo figure at his desk. The room, newly devoid of a mother's supervision, is untidy, with comic books and other plastic models constructed and painted by Joe, including autos, monsters, and a locomotive. All the boys look on, and their faces illuminate. Headlights emerge, and the boys rise as a yellow Buick halts beside them, driven by 14-year-old Alice Dainard. She perceives Joe, looking away, irritated, as all the boys silently await. She considers, shakes her head, and the boys eagerly scurry into the car. The Buick traverses the nocturnal skyline through a pastoral terrain. Cary fiddles with the radio, Alice glances at him in the rearview, their eyes connect briefly, she takes the Twizzler he offers, and looks back to the road. Joe strolls past Alice, who watches him, while Martin sits alone, reading and committing lines to memory, and she looks at him as if searching for something. Joe ceases stippling, the strain is almost overwhelming, and he indicates the sponge for make-up, which she uses. Joe begins applying make-up to Alice's eyelids, sensing something provocative in being so close to her with her eyes shut. Alice is made up, wearing a coat with a handbag, as Martin, in a tie, faces her, both looking over script pages while Charles adjusts the camera. Joe watches, holding the boom microphone as Preston wears a trench coat. Abruptly, a pop! Everyone jumps as Cary, chuckling, detonates a firecracker. Martin and Alice enact as Detective John Hathaway and Mrs. Rebecca Hathaway, with Preston performing in the background. Ultimately, we focus closely on Joe, observing Alice.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Joe and Charles enter; Charles grabs a roll. Joe nods as Jack smiles, closing the bathroom door, leaving Joe stunned. Joe and his father, in civvies, sit at the counter. Jack shows Joe a Hewitt Sports Camp pamphlet with images of happy kids. Joe looks at it while holding his mother's locket. Jack wants to cry but turns away. In Joe's messy room, he paints a Quasimodo model, surrounded by his comic books and models. The boys watch as a yellow Buick driven by 14-year-old Alice Dainard stops. She sees Joe, who looks away, then the boys eagerly enter the car. The Buick drives through the rural night. Cary fiddles with the radio, exchanges a look with Alice, offers her a Twizzler, and she accepts. Joe walks past Alice, who observes him, while Martin reads lines. Joe stops stippling and indicates make-up; he applies it to Alice's eyelids, feeling provoked by her closed eyes. Alice, in a coat, and Martin, in a tie, review the script. Charles adjusts the camera as Joe holds the boom mike. Cary laughs, setting off a firecracker. Martin and Alice perform their roles, with Preston nearby. We focus on Joe, watching Alice.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
Joe and Charles make their entrance together, and Charles immediately reaches out and grabs a roll. Joe acknowledges this action with a nod. Meanwhile, Jack attempts to force a smile, closing the bathroom door, which leaves Joe feeling stunned and deeply heartsick. Sitting side by side, Joe and his father, both dressed in civilian clothes, are positioned comfortably at the counter. Jack thoughtfully takes out a pamphlet and places it on the table before Joe, revealing a promotional leaflet for Hewitt Sports Camp, complete with images of cheerful, smiling, and health-conscious athletic children. Joe glances back at the pamphlet, his other hand, previously unseen, emerges from beneath the table, and it becomes evident to Jack that Joe is clutching his mother's locket. Feeling an overwhelming urge to cry yet again and an impulse to discard the locket, Jack ultimately just turns away, while Joe continues to fixate on the pamphlet. 

In the quiet, personal space of Joe's room, he holds a paintbrush in his hand, diligently working on a model of Quasimodo at his desk. The room, which now lacks the meticulous touch of a mother's care, is in disarray, filled with scattered comic books and various other plastic models crafted and painted by Joe, including detailed cars, imaginative creatures, and an intricate train model. All the boys are looking on, their faces lighting up with excitement. Headlights suddenly become visible, and the boys quickly rise to their feet as a yellow Buick, driven by the 14-year-old Alice Dainard, comes to a stop beside them. Alice notices Joe, who is turning his gaze away, visibly annoyed, while all the boys wait in silence, holding their breath. She considers her options, shakes her head, and then the boys eagerly scramble into the car with enthusiasm. The Buick travels across the nighttime horizon, moving through the serene rural landscape. Cary fiddles with the radio, catching Alice's attention in the rearview mirror; their eyes meet and hold for a moment. She accepts a Twizzler he offers, turning her attention back to the road ahead. 

Joe is walking past Alice, who watches him with a keen eye, while Martin sits in solitude, absorbed in reading and memorizing his lines, and she looks at him as though searching for something elusive. Joe halts his stippling work, the tension in the air thick and almost unbearable, and he gestures towards the sponge meant for make-up, which she uses. Joe begins to apply make-up delicately to Alice's eyelids, feeling a sense of intrigue in being so near to her while her eyes remain gently closed. Alice, now fully made up, is dressed in a coat with a purse slung over her shoulder, as Martin, wearing a tie, stands facing her, both of them glancing over script pages while Charles adjusts the camera equipment. Joe observes from his position, holding the boom mike, as Preston dons an overcoat. Suddenly, there is a loud pop! Everyone reacts with a jump as Cary, laughing, sets off a firecracker. Martin and Alice immerse themselves in their roles as Detective John Hathaway and Mrs. Rebecca Hathaway, with Preston contributing to the scene in the background. In the end, our attention is drawn tightly to Joe, who is intently watching Alice.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
Together, Joe and Charles make their grand entrance, and without hesitation, Charles immediately reaches out to grab a roll. Joe acknowledges this action with nothing more than a subtle nod of understanding. Meanwhile, Jack, standing nearby, attempts to muster a smileâ€”a forced oneâ€”while he gently closes the bathroom door. This leaves Joe feeling not just surprised but profoundly heartsick and stunned. Seated side by side, Joe and his father find themselves both dressed in civilian clothes, positioned comfortably at the counter. Jack, with a thoughtful expression, takes out a pamphlet, carefully placing it on the table in front of Joe. This pamphlet is essentially a promotional leaflet for Hewitt Sports Camp, complete with vivid images of cheerful, smiling, and health-conscious athletic children. As Joe glances back at the pamphlet, his other hand, which was previously hidden from view, emerges from beneath the table. It becomes evident to Jack that Joe is clutching his mother's locket. Feeling an overwhelming urge to cry once more and an impulse to discard the locket, Jack ultimately decides to simply turn away, while Joe continues to fixate on the pamphlet.

In the quiet, personal refuge of Joe's room, he holds a paintbrush in his hand, diligently working at his desk on a model of Quasimodo. The room, once touched by a mother's meticulous care, now lies in disarray, filled with scattered comic books and various other plastic models crafted and painted by Joe. These include detailed cars, imaginative creatures, and an intricate train model. All the boys observe intently, their faces lighting up with pure excitement. Suddenly, headlights become visible, prompting the boys to quickly rise to their feet. A yellow Buick, driven by 14-year-old Alice Dainard, comes to an eventual stop beside them. Alice notices Joe, who, visibly annoyed, turns his gaze away, while all the boys stand silently, holding their breath in anticipation. She considers her options, shakes her head slightly, and then the boys scramble eagerly into the car with enthusiasm. The Buick travels across the nighttime horizon, smoothly moving through the serene rural landscape. Cary, sitting inside, fiddles with the radio, catching Alice's attention in the rearview mirror. Their eyes meet and hold for a brief moment, a silent exchange between them. She accepts a Twizzler he offers, turning her attention back to the road lying ahead.

Joe finds himself walking past Alice, who watches him with a keen and observant eye, while Martin sits alone, completely absorbed in reading and memorizing his lines, as she looks at him as though searching for something elusive. Joe halts his stippling work; the tension in the air is thick, palpable, and almost unbearable. He gestures towards the sponge meant for make-up, which she uses. Joe then begins to apply make-up delicately to Alice's eyelids, feeling a sense of intrigue and fascination at being so near to her while her eyes remain gently closed. Alice, now fully made up, is dressed in a coat with a purse slung over her shoulder. Martin, wearing a tie, stands facing her, both of them glancing over the script pages, while Charles busily adjusts the camera equipment. Joe observes from his position, holding the boom mike, as Preston dons an overcoat. Suddenly, there is a loud pop! Everyone jumps in reaction as Cary, laughing, sets off a firecracker. Martin and Alice immerse themselves in their roles as Detective John Hathaway and Mrs. Rebecca Hathaway, with Preston contributing to the scene in the background. In the end, our focus is drawn tightly to Joe, who is intently and closely watching Alice.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: As Joe and Charles enter the room, Charles swiftly moves towards the table and grabs a roll, while Joe stands by, his eyes following Charles's actions. Simultaneously, Jack, who is nearby, forces a smile in Joe's direction in a strained attempt to convey normalcy, before he decisively swings the bathroom door shut, leaving Joe momentarily frozen, grappling with a surge of emotions that leave him stunned and heartsick. Joe and his father sit side by side at the counter, dressed casually, their attire reflecting their relaxed state. Jack, with a sense of purpose, retrieves a pamphlet from his pocket and deliberately places it on the table in front of Joe, revealing glossy photographs of cheerful, healthy-looking athletic kids at Hewitt Sports Camp. As Joeâ€™s gaze lingers on the pamphlet, one of his hands emerges from beneath the table, and it becomes apparent that he is clutching his mother's locket, a symbol of lingering attachment. Jack, observing this poignant reminder of the past, feels a surge of emotions welling up, fighting an urge to discard the locket, but instead, he merely turns his head away, leaving Joe to quietly contemplate the pamphlet. Later, in the solitude of Joe's room, he holds a paintbrush with determined focus, meticulously applying delicate strokes to a model of Quasimodo on his desk. The room, now free from a mother's meticulous oversight, is in disarray, strewn with comic books and various plastic modelsâ€”a testament to Joe's creative endeavors, including cars, creatures, and a trainâ€”all meticulously constructed and painted by his hand. As the boys gather, a palpable sense of anticipation fills the air, their faces lighting up in unison. Headlights suddenly break the darkness, and the boys' attention shifts to a yellow Buick pulling up beside them, driven by spirited 14-year-old Alice Dainard. She briefly meets Joe's gaze, her expression tinged with annoyance, while the boys stand in silent expectation. Pondering the situation, she gives a slight shake of her head, prompting the boys to eagerly scurry into the car. The Buick traverses the darkened rural landscape, a sense of adventure in its path. Inside, Cary fiddles with the radio, drawing a glance from Alice in the rearview mirror, their eyes locking in a moment of silent communication. As Cary extends a Twizzler, Alice accepts it and refocuses on the road ahead. Later, Joe walks past Alice, who observes him quietly, while Martin occupies himself by rehearsing lines, his focus intense as Alice watches him with a curiosity that suggests she is searching for something more. Joe, pausing his stippling work, feels a mounting tension and gestures toward the makeup sponge, which Alice uses with trust. He begins applying makeup to her eyelids, an intimacy in proximity creating an unexpectedly provocative sensation as her closed eyes add to the moment's vulnerability. With Alice now fully made up and clad in a coat with a purse slung over her shoulder, she stands opposite Martin, who is neatly dressed in a tie. Together, they review script pages, their focus converging as Charles adjusts the camera to capture the scene. Joe stands back, observing intently while managing the boom mic, and Preston, in an overcoat, readies himself for the unfolding scene. Suddenly, a loud pop reverberates through the air, jolting everyone as Cary, unable to contain his amusement, detonates a firecracker. Amidst the excitement, Martin and Alice resume their roles, embodying Detective John Hathaway and Mrs. Rebecca Hathaway with Preston supporting in the backdrop. Finally, our focus narrows in on Joe, who is absorbed, his attention locked on Alice, captivated by her presence and the moment unfolding before him.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description:
Joe and Charles enter the room, and after Charles grabs a roll, Joe exchanges a nod with Jack, who forces a smile before closing the bathroom door, leaving Joe feeling stunned and heartsick. Later, Joe and his father sit at the counter in civilian clothes as Jack presents a pamphlet for Hewitt Sports Camp, featuring images of happy, athletic kids. Joe glances at the pamphlet while holding his mother's locket, prompting Jack to turn away, suppressing his emotions. In his room, Joe paints a Quasimodo model amidst the clutter of comic books and models he built, reflecting the absence of his mother's oversight. 

As evening falls, all the boys wait with anticipation, their faces lighting up as a yellow Buick driven by 14-year-old Alice Dainard approaches. Alice notices Joe's annoyed demeanor but lets the boys excitedly scramble into the car, which drives through the rural night. Inside, Cary fiddles with the radio, sharing a moment with Alice in the rearview mirror before offering her a Twizzler, which she accepts. 

Meanwhile, Joe walks past Alice while Martin, sitting alone, memorizes lines. Alice watches him intently, as if searching for something. Joe pauses his stippling and indicates the make-up sponge for Alice, feeling a provocative closeness as he applies make-up to her eyelids. With Alice in character, wearing a coat and purse, she and Martin review script pages as Charles adjusts the camera. Joe observes this dynamic while holding the boom mike, alongside Preston in an overcoat. Suddenly, Cary startles everyone by exploding a firecracker with a laugh. Martin and Alice then perform as Detective John Hathaway and Mrs. Rebecca Hathaway, complemented by Prestonâ€™s background role. The scene closes on Joe, who intently watches Alice.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Joe and Charles enter the kitchen of their family home, and Charles grabs a roll from the counter where breakfast is laid out. Joe nods as Jack, who is struggling with his emotions over a recent family loss, forces a smile and closes the bathroom door, leaving Joe stunned and heartsick. Joe and his father, dressed in civilian clothes as Joe's father is a retired military officer, sit beside each other at the counter. Jack pulls out a pamphlet and places it on the table, showing Joe a pamphlet for Hewitt Sports Camp, a well-regarded summer camp in the region known for its focus on developing young athletes, with images of happy, smiling, healthy athletic kids. Joe looks back at the pamphlet, his other hand coming up from under the table, and Jack sees that Joe is holding his mother's locket, a cherished family heirloom passed down through generations. Jack wants to cry again and throw the locket away but just turns away as Joe stares at the pamphlet. In Joe's room, he holds a paintbrush, working on a Quasimodo model at his desk, a testament to his love for classic literature and film. The room, recently devoid of a mother's oversight since her passing, is messy, with comic books and other plastic models built and painted by Joe, including cars, creatures, and a train, reflecting his creative interests. All the boys look on, and their faces brighten. Headlights appear, and the boys stand as a yellow Buick, a symbol of mid-century Americana, stops beside them, driven by 14-year-old Alice Dainard, well-known in their circle for her rebellious spirit. She sees Joe, looking away, annoyed, as all the boys silently wait. She considers, shakes her head, and the boys excitedly scramble into the car. The Buick crosses the nighttime horizon through a rural landscape, highlighting the open fields and starry skies of their hometown. Cary messes with the radio, tuning through static before landing on a classic rock station, Alice looks at him in the rearview, their eyes hold a beat, she takes the Twizzler he offers, and looks back to the road. Joe walks past Alice, who watches him, while Martin sits alone, reading and memorizing lines for the school play, and she looks at him as if searching for something. Joe stops stippling, the tension is almost too much, and he indicates the sponge for make-up, which she uses expertly, having practiced in her free time. Joe starts applying make-up to Alice's eyelids, feeling something provocative in being so close to her with her eyes closed. Alice is made up, wearing a coat with a purse, as Martin, in a tie, faces her, both looking over script pages while Charles adjusts the camera, his passion for filmmaking evident in his precise preparations. Joe observes, holding the boom mike as Preston wears an overcoat, preparing for his supporting role. Suddenly, a pop! Everyone jumps as Cary, laughing, explodes a firecracker, an act typical of his prankster personality. Martin and Alice perform as Detective John Hathaway and Mrs. Rebecca Hathaway, with Preston acting in the background, contributing to the overall scene of their independent film project. Finally, we focus tightly on Joe, watching Alice, his admiration for her growing as they work together.

Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. his every desperate step a race against time to save lives in the midst of utter devastation. Cary messes with the radio. Alice looks at him in the rearview. their eyes hold a beat. she takes the Twizzler he offers and looks back to the road. Joe walks past Alice who watches him while Martin sits alone reading and memorizing lines and she looks at him as if searching for something. Joe stops stippling. the tension is almost too much and he indicates the sponge for makeup which she uses. Joe starts applying makeup to Alice's eyelids feeling something provocative in being so close to her with her eyes closed. Alice is made up wearing a coat with a purse as Martin in a tie faces her both looking over script pages while Charles adjusts the camera. Joe observes holding the boom mike as Preston wears an overcoat. Suddenly a pop. Everyone jumps as Cary laughing explodes a firecracker. Martin and Alice perform as Detective John Hathaway and Mrs Rebecca Hathaway with Preston acting in the background. Finally we focus tightly on Joe watching Alice.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~50%)
test_cases.description: Joe and Charles enter and Charles grabs a roll. Joe nods as Jack forces a smile and closes the bathroom door leaving Joe stunned and heartsick. Joe and his father in civvies sit beside each other at the counter. Jack pulls out a pamphlet and places it on the table showing Joe a pamphlet for Hewitt Sports Camp with images of happy smiling healthy athletic kids. Joe looks back at the pamphlet his other hand coming up from under the table and Jack sees that Joe is holding his mother's locket. Jack wants to cry again and throw the locket away but just turns away as Joe stares at the pamphlet. In Joe's room he holds a paintbrush working on a Quasimodo model at his desk. Joe starts applying makeup to Alice's eyelids feeling something provocative in being so close to her with her eyes closed. Alice is made up wearing a coat with a purse as Martin in a tie faces her both looking over script pages while Charles adjusts the camera. Joe observes holding the boom mike as Preston wears an overcoat. Suddenly a pop. Everyone jumps as Cary laughing explodes a firecracker. Martin and Alice perform as Detective John Hathaway and Mrs Rebecca Hathaway with Preston acting in the background. Finally we focus tightly on Joe watching Alice.

Joe and his father in civvies sit beside each other at the counter. Everyone jumps as Cary laughing explodes a firecracker. Martin and Alice perform as Detective John Hathaway and Mrs Rebecca Hathaway with Preston acting in the background. Finally we focus tightly on Joe watching Alice.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Tim and Roger stroll in, and Roger snatches a bagel. Tim winks as Max fakes a chuckle and shuts the closet door, leaving Tim bewildered and heartbroken. Tim and his uncle, dressed in uniforms, lounge beside each other on the sofa. Max pulls out a brochure and sets it on the couch, showing Tim a flyer for Greenwood Adventure Retreat, with pictures of joyful, grinning, lively athletic adults. Tim glances back at the brochure, his other hand emerging from behind the couch, and Max observes that Tim is clutching his grandmother's bracelet. Max longs to laugh again and toss the bracelet aside but instead turns around as Tim gazes at the brochure. In Tim's attic, he grips a screwdriver, tinkering on a Frankenstein figurine at his table. The attic, recently lacking an aunt's direction, is cluttered, with novels and other wooden sculptures crafted and polished by Tim, including planes, monsters, and a boat. All the men observe, and their expressions brighten. Taillights emerge, and the men rise as a blue Chevy pauses beside them, driven by 15-year-old Sue Greenfield. She spots Tim, glancing away, irritated, as all the men quietly anticipate. She reflects, nods her head, and the men eagerly clamber into the vehicle. The Chevy glides across the daytime skyline through an urban scenery. Harry fiddles with the cassette player, Sue looks at him in the side mirror, their glances connect for a moment, she accepts the candy he hands over, and focuses back on the drive. Tim strolls by Sue, who observes him, while Michael sits isolated, studying and rehearsing lines, and she glances at him as if searching for clues. Tim ceases sketching, the tension is nearly unbearable, and he gestures towards the brush for face paint, which she utilizes. Tim starts dabbing face paint onto Sue's cheeks, sensing something stirring in being so near to her with her eyes shut. Sue is painted up, wearing a jacket with a backpack, as Michael, in a scarf, faces her, both glancing over script sheets while Roger adjusts the tripod. Tim watches, holding the sound recorder as Bradley dons a trench coat. Abruptly, a bang! Everyone leaps as Harry, giggling, detonates a smoke bomb. Michael and Sue perform as Officer Mike Harper and Ms. Charlotte Harper, with Bradley enacting in the background. Ultimately, we focus intently on Tim, observing Sue.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby cafÃ©, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Joe and Charles enter, and Charles grabs a roll. Joe is left stunned and heartsick when Jack closes the bathroom door. At the counter, Jack shows Joe a pamphlet for Hewitt Sports Camp, but Joe, holding his mother's locket, remains detached. In Joe's messy room, devoid of a mother's oversight, he's painting a Quasimodo model. Later, 14-year-old Alice Dainard drives up in a yellow Buick; after a pause, the boys excitedly get in. As Cary plays with the radio, Alice watches him and takes a Twizzler he offers. Joe applies make-up to Alice, feeling a connection. Alice, made-up, and Martin, in a tie, rehearse script pages as Charles adjusts the camera. The scene is interrupted by Caryâ€™s firecracker, but the group continues filming, with Martin and Alice as Detective and Mrs. Hathaway. Joe intensely observes Alice throughout.
